bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 7, 1876

div1.p: Reed describes sleigh rides he has taken with the ladies of the army base at Willet's Point. He teases Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 7, 1876
div1.p:
With truth, I
might exclaim “snow, snow,
nothing but snow”! For we
have had plenty of it. Friday mor-
ning, I awoke to find the earth
mantled in white, pure white,
such as dazzles & blinds the
eye. 'Twas the first heavy snow
that we have had, this winter, and
hence we were proud of it.
Of course, the only topic of our
conversation was sleighing-
to which we looked forward
with much pleasant antici-
pation; and I am happy to say
that we were not disappointed.
The day was all that one could
wish - bright & beautiful, though
very cold. I did not go sleighing
during the day but at 7.30 P.M.
Lieutenant Young called by for
me in his “nobby” little Cutter,
to which was hitched an ani-
mal that can make a mile in
less than three minutes. Seat-
ing myself by his side & draw-
ing the heavy robes closely about
us, we were soon speeding
with the wind- Oh! it was char-
ming! The jingling music of
the sleigh-bells, the crisp, cold
air, the flying snow, the silver
moon over head, all combined
to make a most beautiful win-
ter-scenes, & one that I shall
long remember- But withal;
my darling Emilie, it lacked
the charm of your presence!
without which no scene
of my life can be complete.
I am not done telling you of
the grand times we had sleighing.
Saturday Morning, Lieut. Symons
& I procured a team & sleigh,
(the latter large enough to seat
nine)- for the purpose of giving
the ladies of the Post the benefit
of a trip over the snow- We left
the Post with six ladies & one
gentleman, besides ourselves,
& a merrier party never were
brought together- There were
Mrs. King, Mrs. Heger, Mrs. Tabor,
Mrs. Abbott, Mrs. Oxholm & Miss
Abbott- Of course, it was im-
possible for such a jolly crowd
to return without some ac-
cident- We had gone about
6 miles & were having “no thought
for the morrow,” when sud-
denly one of the runners
of our sleigh broke, & down we
came, all in a bunch! We did
not care for this, & instead of in-
terrupting the jollity of our ride,
it only served to increase it.
We were in the town of Flushing
when the accident occurred, so
we were enabled to quickly pro-
cure other sleighs- Two others
were soon found & dividing
our party, Mrs. King, Mrs. Tabor, &
myself, in one sleigh, & the remain-
der in another, we were soon
on our way home, as merry
as ever,-where we arrived safely-
This, my darling, is an incident
of Army life. I am happy to hear
that you have such an addition
to the intelligence of M'boro. Since
his name is not Reed, I expect
that you will greatly admire him-
Excuse brevity-
div1.closer:
As ever, my darling,
your fond & devoted Walter.
P.S. Kindest regards
to Miss A. & Mrs.
Harrold-
W.
